interlinear-text.item: Recorded by Husniya Khujamyorova in Vrang, Tajikistan, June, 2016.

phrase.item: Okay, I am living in ninetieth of my life (ninety years old).
I remember our way of life in the period from around 1935 to 1936, when I gained wisdom.
Back then, our conditions were not good.
It was hard because there was no transportation, there were no car roads.
All our hope was placed in the land of our village, Vrang.
If it gave us crops, we would have bread. If not, we would have nothing.
People would go from here all the way to Badakhshan or Fayzobod, or to Afghanistan to meet their needs [for food].
Or they could go via Jinif (a street in Vrang) to Chitral, Pakistan.
From there, they could bring rock salt, about ten kilos of rice, one or two kilos of tea, and that was it.
After that, there came the [Soviet] kolkhoz, the collective farm.
When the collective farm came, for one or two or three years life became easier. Then Hitler's rubob started, the war began. May God take war away somewhere and never bring it back.
It was impossble to find bread.
They used to cook ɣazg (a type of herb), there wasn't salt, but there was nitrate [from the riverside].
They could bring that and soak it in a big bowl, then they would boil the herb and mix it with that, in order to survive.
During the war, life was very tough
Life like that was "bitterness and stone".
Until '48,
in 1948, there were ration cards.
Flour and everything were given through the "ticket".
For example, one person could get 500 grams of flour.
You would hand over the ticket and they would give you (flour).
When they stopped giving tickets, the car road opened as far the village Shitharv.
People made [the roads] by themselves,
by the power of their own hands.
There were no tractors, trucks, or bulldozers. They just used ammonal [a type of dynamite] to break the mountain rocks.
People were gathered from Goron (village name) to Kiçn (village name).
From Sarsi Kul to Shitharv, they built roads with their own power.
When the cars srarted going and the goverment also started helping with suger, flour and all these things were brought to us.
From around the year 1948, life started getting better.
It got much better until the year from around 1990 to 1992, when life became hard again.
There was no transportation, [cars] were not allowed, and there was less food.
Then our head, our president [of Tajikistan] made a request to [made an agreement with] Hazir Imam [Aga Khan].
The present Imam came to the Ishkashim [region],
We were all taken from here to Ishkashim.
He made a speech to us there.
Then he left, and he took us under his wing.
Flour, oil, rice and everything here,
all these were sent by him to us.
up until the restoration of the Republic of Tajikistan.
Imomali became the president, and in the time of his presidency, people got accustomed to a more comfortable life.
Well, not just a simple life, but living in a comfortable way.
Nowadays here in Vrang itself, there are more than 70 cars in movement.
People are not in need.
Well, there is food, flour, rice, oil, and meat, we have everything.
Even in every family, there are qolin [ornate wall hangings] all over the walls.
What was called 'daroshka' in [our language]?
Carpet? [kavjor]?
No, [kavjor] in Russian!
The old version?
[chdar]?
carpet [plos]?
Karpet [pojandoz]!
Poyandoz [carpet] on the floor, nowadays even a widowed woman will have them.
The families who have a good income, they have everything.
Everything they have.
Now I compare life nowadays with the past life, year like '35, '36, and we are living like kings.
We are living like kings, we have everything.
There is everything.
Well, this was my life story from my childhood up until now.
